newsitem.title: USA: GOLF-PLAY RESUMES; LEHMAN, WOODS AND ELS CHASE MONTGOMERIE.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-PLAY RESUMES; LEHMAN, WOODS AND ELS CHASE MONTGOMERIE.

text.p: Tom Lehman and Tiger Woods each lost some ground in pursuit of leader Colin Montgomerie Friday as both players were bit by the bogey bug after sitting out a delay of more than two hours at the U.S. Open.
The championship chase was stalled for two hours, 18 minutes due to a threat of lightning in the vicinity of Congressional Country Club.
After play was resumed at 2:10 p.m. (1810 GMT), Masters champion Woods bogeyed the 17th and British Open champion Lehman, playing in the same group, went on to bogey 18.

Lehman finished the round at even-par 70 to remain three under par for the tournament, while the 21-year-old Woods posted a three-under 67 to climb to one over par after starting the championship with a 74 on Thursday.

Montgomerie, who had not yet teed off when play was suspended, later parred the first hole but bogeyed the second to stand at four under par, slipping back into a tie with Hal Sutton, who had yet to begin his second round.

Woods, who began the day four over par, had stormed out to a 31 on the front nine after making four birdies without a blemish. As on Thursday, however, when he went six over par over the last eight holes, the young phenomenon had his troubles on the back nine.
Woods bogeyed the unlucky 13th, birdied the 14th and 15th, then bogeyed the 16th and 17th in his up-and-down inward half.

Ernie Els, the 1994 U.S. Open champion, also fired a four-under score of 31 on the front nine to reach three under par, before posting two bogeys and a birdie coming in. He finished with a round of 67 to stand two under par.
